results.title: Desire
results.brief_description: This clever, noirish comedy is shot in black and white without dialogue by the director of Australian hit movies Love and Other Catastrophes (1996) and Strange Planet. (1999) A lonely laboratory worker becomes obsessed with a woman on a train - with deadly consequences.

results.title: Just
results.brief_description: In a room above a street, Radiohead play their song, ‘Just’. In the street below, a man lies on the ground, attracting a number of concerned, irritated and worried passers-by. But his condition may be contagious…..

results.title: Luz
results.brief_description: 128…129…129…a walk through a wondrous neighbourhood that only a child could imagine. A little girl plays in the street while her mother calls her home, wherever we find it.

results.title: Bsss
results.brief_description: A fly meets an elephant…by the book! A fly buzzes around a room landing upon a book with pictures of an elephant inside. The fly appears to investigate the drawing. A human squashes the fly into the book. Fly and elephant are united. (Screened at MISAF, October 2000.)

results.title: Lazy Sunday afternoon
results.brief_description: In the desert a vulture enjoys the silence of a hot afternoon. The sudden appearance of a vehicle destroys the quiet of the day. Two pistoleros exit the car ready for a duel; our hero, the vulture, watches as the pistoleros take part in a very funny slow motion shoot-out.

results.title: Robots: the animated docu-soap
results.brief_description:
Just another day in the life of three ordinary robots suffering for their art - Jackson, a painter/sculptor; Roland, a composer/musician; and Hands, a champion skater. This award-winning animated film tracks the demise of the three redundant robots as they attempt to reassert meaning into their empty lives. Made in the style of a documentary-soap and containing a rather dark sense of humour, this is a somewhat offbeat satirical depiction of the genre.
Voice: David Hopewell. (Awards: Best New British Animation, Edinburgh International Film Festival 2000; Jury Award, Art Film Festival 2001)

results.title: No. 1 On the Charts : A Look at the Australian Pop Music Industry
results.creator_credit: TV Ed Productions, David Ferris, Trevor Lunn and Don Fitzsimmons
results.brief_description: Lee Simon, Basia Bonkowski, Jane Clifton and Michael Gudinski are interviewed in a forum style program about their views on the presentation of popular culture in the media. Video clips are interposed throughout the program.

results.title: Not Crippled, Not Useless
results.brief_description: Michael Briffa is fourteen and will probably be confined to a wheelchair for the rest of his life. This program explores Michael’s determination and success in being allowed to enrol in an ordinary school. As well, Michael’s parents discuss their attitudes to special schools.

results.title: Versatility in glass
results.brief_description:
Public relations film outlining the nature of glass: how it is made; how it can be used in its many and varied forms for decoration, safety and protection in the home, industry and transportation.
Suitable for upper primary and lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Khmer! Khmer!: Cambodia in conflict (D)
results.creator_credit: Experimental Film and Television Fund, ABC and James G. Gerrand
results.brief_description: Portrays the life, culture, history and politics of the Cambodians. Focuses on Norodom Sihanouk’s abdication from the throne and becoming the first Democratic Leader of Cambodia, thus destroying the old feudal system and through to social and political destruction during the Vietnam War. Narrated by Richard Oxenburgh. WARNING: Contains graphic scenes of war related deaths.
